metadata.case_name: Ambica Mills Co. Ltd. v. Textile Labour Association & Ors.

facts.text: Appellant Shri Ambica Mills Co. Ltd. is a textile mill working at Ahmedabad.

Standardisation Award pronounced by Industrial Tribunal on April 21, 1948, in Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1947, fixed wages for different categories of workers in Ahmedabad textile mills, including hand-folders at Rs. 36-9-0 per month, but left clerks for future decision. Tribunal directed that persons doing cut-looking as well as folding should be paid rate of out-lookers in Bombay (head Rs. 52, cut-looker Rs. 42-4-0).

Agreement between Ahmedabad Mill Owners Association and Textile Labour Association on June 22, 1949, on wages for clerks. Clause 2 applies to clerks doing routine work of writing, copying or making calculations, including compounders. Clause 5 provides separate scale Rs. 40-3-70-EB-4-90-5-105 for employees lower than full-fledged clerk but higher than operative, listing ticket-boy, cut-looker etc.

Vishnuprasad and Punamchand applied to authority under s.16 Payment of Wages Act in Applications Nos. 39 and 40 of 1954, claiming delayed wages as entitled to higher wages under para 16 of 1948 Award. Authority rejected mill's contentions, found they were folders doing cut-looking, entitled to Rs. 42-4-0, ordered difference from Rs. 36-9-0. Decision on September 2, 1954.
Three employees (Punamchand, Shamaldas, Vishnuprasad) via respondents moved authority under s.16 on July 11, 1955, claiming semi-clerk status under cl.5 of 1949 agreement, entitled to increments.

Authority resisted by appellant on res judicata, jurisdiction, merits. Raised issues, held against respondents on res judicata (for Punamchand, Vishnuprasad) and status (not semi-clerks). Duties per joint Pursis not routine clerical. Governed by Standardisation Award, not agreement.

Appellate authority (District Judge) on September 2, 1954? (text says appeals dismissed September 2, 1954, but earlier 1954 decision was Sept 2; likely 1956 or typo), held jurisdiction exists, res judicata applies to two, not semi-clerks, applied cl.2 test to cl.5.

Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 874 of 1958, judgment April 24, 1958, allowed writ under Arts. 226/227, set aside orders, remanded to authority. Held appellate authority erred in assuming cl.2 determinative for cl.5, res judicata finding erroneous.
Employees are bleach-folders classified as Uttarnars and Chadhavnars, duties admitted. Ahmedabad mills have no separate cut-lookers as in Bombay; work done by bleach-folders.
Both Award and agreement in operation for respective persons.

legal_issues.text: Nature and extent of jurisdiction conferred on the authority by s.15 of the Payment of Wages Act, 1936.
Whether High Court exceeded jurisdiction under Arts. 226/227 in interfering with appellate authority via certiorari for error in construing cls. 2 and 5 of 1949 agreement.
Whether applications under s.15 competent where dispute is whether employees fall under cl.5 of agreement or Standardisation Award.
Res judicata from prior authority decision on cut-looking claim.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court exceeded jurisdiction under Arts. 226/227; error by appellate authority is not apparent on face of record.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226; precedents like Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmad Ishaque

petitioner_arguments.text: Authority under s.15 has limited jurisdiction only for deductions/delay in wages, not to determine if employee falls under cl.5 category without designation (requires enquiry into duties/category). Must go to industrial court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Payment of Wages Act s.15, s.22; A.V. D'Costa v. B. Patel; Anthony Sabastin Almeda v. R.M.T. Taylor

petitioner_arguments.text: Applications barred by res judicata; employees operatives under Award, not semi-clerks.

respondent_arguments.text: Employees semi-clerks under cl.5 of agreement, position higher than operative, lower than full clerk; entitled to scale.
Prior claim under Award para 16 different; res judicata does not apply.

court_reasoning.text: High Court justified in certiorari as appellate authority's construction of cls.2 and 5 patently erroneous: cl.2 for clerks, cl.5 expressly for those not clerks not operatives, list shows no need for cl.2 test.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error manifest and obvious on face of record; plain misreading ignoring separate provisions.

court_reasoning.text: s.15 jurisdiction includes incidental questions to deductions/delay, like terms of contract. Here, both contracts subsisting, admitted; dispute only which applies (Award or cl.5) intimately connected to wages definition s.2(vi).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unreasonable to exclude; no artificial limitation. Differs from cases of rival contracts.

court_reasoning.text: Prior authority finding that applicants folders doing cut-looking favors respondents, not res judicata against them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correct on res judicata.

holdings.text: Authority under s.15 has jurisdiction to decide if employee falls under particular wage category in subsisting contract where relation/duties admitted.
Error in construing agreement cls.2/5 apparent on face, correctable by certiorari under Art.226.
Res judicata does not bar claims of Punamchand/Vishnuprasad.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari corrects errors of law apparent on face of record, even if not jurisdictional.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nagendra Nath Bora v. Commissioner of Hills Division
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari for errors of law apparent, not facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hari Vishnu Kamath v. Syed Ahmad Ishaque
precedents_cited.relevance: Error apparent if self-evident without elaborate argument.
Authority jurisdiction over actual contract terms/wages, not potential.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vishwanath Tukaram v. General Manager, Central Railway
Maharaja Sri Umaid Mills Ltd. v. Collector of Pali
Anthony Sabastin Almeda v. R.M.T. Taylor
precedents_cited.relevance: No jurisdiction where rival contracts pleaded as to which subsists.

statutes_cited.name: Payment of Wages Act, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines wages, wage period, time of payment, deductions; authority jurisdiction limited to claims from deductions/delay, exclusive, includes incidental contract terms.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction to correct errors apparent on face via certiorari.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave against Bombay High Court order setting aside lower authorities' decisions and remanding dismissed. Supreme Court upheld High Court on jurisdiction under s.15, error in agreement construction apparent, res judicata erroneous.
outcome.relief_granted: Case stands remanded to authority as per High Court order.

key_quotes.text: "the error committed by the appellate authority was of such a manifest character that the High Court was justified in correcting the said error by the issue of a writ of certiorari."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds High Court intervention proper for patent error.

key_quotes.text: "it would be unreasonable to exclude the decision of such a question from the jurisdiction of the authority under s. 15."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms s.15 includes category disputes incidental to wages.

key_quotes.text: "Clause 5, on the other hand, obviously provides for a separate scale for those employees who are not clerks not operatives."
key_quotes.speaker: court
